pages.text: Tribrachidium heraldicum comes from the Upper Ediacaran, with fossils found in the Flinders Ranges, South Australia; Dniester River, Ukraine; Sonia Formation, India, and the White Sea, Russia. It is a small, rounded lifeform, growing up to 4 cm in diameter. It is noted for its 3 large lobe structures, giving it a rare tri-radial symmetry, something not seen in modern phylums.

The generic name derives from the Greek word 'tria', to mean 'three'; the Latin word 'brachium', to mean 'arm'; and the diminutive suffix of 'idium'. The specific name derives from the well known heraldic triskelion design, due to the similarities in the design and appearance of Tribrachidium from above.
